metadata.title: Cell Structure and Micro-organisms
metadata.subject: Science
metadata.description: This chapter introduces the cell as the basic unit of life, explores plant and animal cell structures, and covers micro-organisms including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protozoa.

preAssessment.question: Which organelle is known as the powerhouse of the cell?
Which of these is found in plant cells but NOT in animal cells?
Which instrument is used to observe cells and micro-organisms?

concepts.title: The Cell: Basic Unit of Life
concepts.content: The cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms. Robert Hooke discovered cells in 1665 while observing cork under a microscope. All living things are made up of one or more cells.

examples.text: Amoeba is a single-celled organism that performs all life functions
The human body contains about 37 trillion cells

keyPoints.text: Cell theory: all living things are made of cells
Unicellular organisms have one cell; multicellular have many
Cells were first observed by Robert Hooke in 1665

concepts.funFact: The largest cell in the human body is the female egg cell (ovum), visible to the naked eye at about 0.1mm!

concepts.title: Animal Cell Structure
concepts.content: An animal cell is surrounded by a cell membrane and contains a nucleus, cytoplasm, mitochondria, ribosomes, and other organelles. It does not have a cell wall, chloroplasts, or a large central vacuole.

examples.text: Red blood cells are animal cells that carry oxygen
Nerve cells (neurons) are long animal cells that transmit signals
Muscle cells contract to produce movement

keyPoints.text: Cell membrane controls entry and exit of substances
Nucleus contains DNA and controls cell activities
Mitochondria produce energy through cellular respiration

concepts.funFact: A single nerve cell (neuron) can be up to 1 metre long ‚Äî stretching from your spine all the way to your toes!

concepts.title: Plant Cell Structure
concepts.content: Plant cells have all the organelles of animal cells, plus a rigid cell wall (made of cellulose), chloroplasts (for photosynthesis), and a large central vacuole for storing water and maintaining turgor pressure.

examples.text: Leaf cells contain many chloroplasts for photosynthesis
Root cells absorb water through osmosis
Guard cells on leaves open and close the stomata

keyPoints.text: Cell wall provides shape and protection to plant cells
Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll, the green pigment for photosynthesis
Large central vacuole maintains water balance

concepts.funFact: The green colour of plants comes from chlorophyll in chloroplasts. In autumn, chlorophyll breaks down revealing yellow and red pigments underneath!

concepts.title: Micro-organisms
concepts.content: Micro-organisms (microbes) are living organisms too small to be seen with the naked eye. They include bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, and algae. Some cause diseases while others are beneficial.

examples.text: Lactobacillus bacteria are used to make curd from milk
Plasmodium protozoa causes malaria, spread by Anopheles mosquitoes
Yeast fungi are used in making bread and idli batter

keyPoints.text: Bacteria can be helpful (nitrogen fixing) or harmful (causing TB)
Viruses are not considered living as they need a host cell to reproduce
Micro-organisms play vital roles in decomposition and nutrient cycling

concepts.funFact: There are more micro-organisms in a handful of soil than there are people who have ever lived on Earth!

concepts.title: Beneficial and Harmful Micro-organisms
concepts.content: While some micro-organisms cause diseases (pathogens), many are essential and beneficial. They help in food production, medicine, and maintaining the health of ecosystems.

examples.text: Penicillin antibiotic was discovered from the mould Penicillium
Rhizobium bacteria fix nitrogen in legume roots, enriching soil
Decomposer fungi and bacteria break down dead matter into nutrients

keyPoints.text: Vaccines use weakened pathogens to build immunity
Antibiotics kill bacteria but do not work on viruses
Good hygiene practices prevent spread of microbial diseases

concepts.funFact: Your gut contains about 100 trillion micro-organisms ‚Äî they help digest food, make vitamins, and protect against harmful bacteria!

test.question: Who proposed the Cell Theory?
test.explanation: Matthias Schleiden and Theodor Schwann proposed the Cell Theory in 1838-39, stating all living things are made of cells.

test.question: Which organelle controls all activities of the cell?
test.explanation: The nucleus contains the genetic material (DNA) and acts as the control centre of the cell.

test.question: What is the function of chloroplasts?
test.explanation: Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll and are the sites of photosynthesis, where sunlight is converted into food.

test.question: Which micro-organism is used to make curd?
test.explanation: Lactobacillus bacteria ferment milk lactose into lactic acid, causing milk to curdle and form curd.

test.question: Which disease is caused by a protozoan?
test.explanation: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium, a protozoan parasite, spread by the female Anopheles mosquito.

test.question: Viruses are different from other micro-organisms because:
options: They can only reproduce inside a host cell
test.explanation: Viruses are not considered fully living because they cannot reproduce on their own ‚Äî they need to infect a host cell.

test.question: What is the function of the cell membrane?
options: Control entry and exit of substances
test.explanation: The cell membrane is semi-permeable, controlling which substances enter and leave the cell.

test.question: Which of the following is found in plant cells but NOT animal cells?
test.explanation: Plant cells have a rigid cell wall made of cellulose outside the cell membrane, which animal cells lack.

keyConcepts: Cell as the basic unit of life
commonMisconceptions: All micro-organisms are harmful ‚Äî many are beneficial
Viruses are living organisms ‚Äî they cannot reproduce without a host
Plant and animal cells are identical ‚Äî plant cells have extra structures
realWorldExamples: Curd and bread making using microbes
Malaria caused by Plasmodium in India

interactiveElement.title: Label the Plant Cell!
interactiveElement.description: Tap on each blank label to reveal the name of the cell organelle.

labels.hint: Controls entry and exit of substances

questions.question:

(a) Diseases spread on a large scale
during periods of heavy rainfall
and floods.
(b) There is a possibility of food
poisoning if we eat stale food.
(c) Soil is turned over during tilling.
(d) Fungus grows quickly in moist or
humid conditions.
(e) A refrigerator is used in almost
every

textbookExercise.rawText:
1. Answer the following questions.

(b) Name the different organelles in a
cell ?
(c) What are micro-organisms ?
(d) Which are the different types of
micro-organisms ?
6. Give reasons.
(a) Diseases spread on a large scale
during periods of heavy rainfall
and floods.
(b) There is a possibility of food
poisoning if we eat stale food.
(c) Soil is turned over during tilling.
(d) Fungus grows quickly in moist or
humid conditions.
(e) A refrigerator is used in almost
every home.
(f) Bread ‚Äòrises‚Äô during baking.
(g) Fodder is soaked in water before
offering to cattle.
2. Fill in the blanks with the proper
word.
(a) The organelle called the ............ is
present in plant cells only.
(b) Garbage is converted into .............
by micro-organisms.
(c) In the cell, photosynthesis is carried

(d) An electron microscope is necessary
for the study of ............... .

and when, a compound microscope?
Explain in detail how you will use
them.
3. What is difference between us?
(a) Plant cell and animal cell.
(b) Prokaryotic cell and eukaryotic cell.

qaCards.question: Who proposed the Cell Theory?
qaCards.answer: Matthias Schleiden and Theodor Schwann proposed the Cell Theory in 1838-39, stating all living things are made of cells.

qaCards.question: Which organelle controls all activities of the cell?
qaCards.answer: The nucleus contains the genetic material (DNA) and acts as the control centre of the cell.

qaCards.question: What is the function of chloroplasts?
qaCards.answer: Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll and are the sites of photosynthesis, where sunlight is converted into food.

qaCards.question: Which micro-organism is used to make curd?
qaCards.answer: Lactobacillus bacteria ferment milk lactose into lactic acid, causing milk to curdle and form curd.

qaCards.question: Which disease is caused by a protozoan?
qaCards.answer: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium, a protozoan parasite, spread by the female Anopheles mosquito.

qaCards.question: Viruses are different from other micro-organisms because:
qaCards.answer: Viruses are not considered fully living because they cannot reproduce on their own ‚Äî they need to infect a host cell.

qaCards.question: What is the function of the cell membrane?
qaCards.answer: The cell membrane is semi-permeable, controlling which substances enter and leave the cell.

qaCards.question: Which of the following is found in plant cells but NOT animal cells?
qaCards.answer: Plant cells have a rigid cell wall made of cellulose outside the cell membrane, which animal cells lack.
